Record.Value: Refresh your knowledge of airlock construction.
Welcome Cadet. To complete this phase of testing and pressurize your base, we will run you through basic airlock construction.
Before we start, looks like your suit's taken some damage. Use duct tape to fix it.
Equip duct tape in active hand from crate.
Let's get started. To build an airlock, start by printing two door kits. You'll need to add ingots from the crate to the autolathe.
You can now print two door kits using the multi-axis molecular compositional system, a.k.a. the autolathe. And begin isolating yourself from the loneliness and disappointment of space.
Before you can construct replacement doors, ODA protocol dictates you must remove the destroyed ones.
Good work. Now build composite doors in the highlighted positions. You'll need to cycle through the options to get the correct door variant.
Place composite door #1 in highlighted position
Place composite door #2 in highlighted position
Connect door #1 to logic and power networks
Connect door #2 to logic and power networks
Build a gas sensor to monitor pressure in the airlock. You'll need to consult the Stationpedia to learn which device fabricates it.
Navigate to 'Kit (Sensors)' page to find fabricator
Build gas sensor in highlighted position
To pressurize an airlock, you need an active vent to cycle air, and a passive vent to allow atmosphere to pass into the pipe network.
Build active vent in highlighted position inside airlock
Build passive vent in highlighted position on base wall
Connect the vents with a pipe network, in order to pump air from the room into the airlock.
Norsec consoles allow you to control and monitor various systems, depending on their configuration. Think of them as a small, simple brain.
Circuitboards provide consoles with a range of different functionality. Here you need an airlock circuitboard, and a datadisk to program it.
Complete the console with glass sheet
To programme the airlock, you'll need a data disk. Then select the items you would like the console to operate. Devices highlight GREEN with RED TEXT when selected.
Now select the airlock doors: selecting the external door as 'Exterior' will cause the other to default to 'Internal'.
When you have successfully completed the airlock set up, the switch on the side of the console will light up green. Remove the data disk from the console to lock it.
The airlock's ready, so now you can pressurize the base! Turn on the APC to fill the room with atmosphere. The system will maintain a 100kPa pressure.
As the room fills with atmosphere, your suit will register the external pressure and temperature change.
Now the base is pressurized, you can test the airlock by pressing 'Cycle to Exterior' on the console.

Good work, Cadet. You've build an airtight, pressurized base. That's the last step of Practical Testing, Phase IV. Return inside and press the 'Complete' button to transmit your results to ODA Stationeer Command.
Turn on APC to start pressurization.
As a Stationeer, you need to finish things: Complete construction of the doors using resources from the crate and your in-built, sub-sentient AI 'tooltip' HUD helper.
Naming items on networks reduces confusion: Use the labeller to name the interior and exterior door on the data network.
